repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Secod Port Modernization and
            Railway Restructuring Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit concurs overall with the
            Implementation Completion Report's (ICR) ratings of
            satisfactory project outcome, likely sustainability,
            substantial institutional development impacts, and
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower, as
            it concerns the Second Port Modernization Project (PMPII);
            yet, regarding the assessment of the Railway Restructuring
            Project (RRP) the audit, although largely concurs with the
            ICR ratings of unsatisfactory project outcome, yet
            substantial institutional development impacts, and
            satisfactory performances by the Bank and Borrower, slightly
            differs on the unlikely sustainability rating, assessing
            this as non evaluable, and, also differs on the ICR Review
            rating of the Borrower, upgrading same from unlikely to
            satisfactory. The audit confirms the following lessons. The
            freedom to operate according to market principles
            potentially makes the operational efficiency of privately
            run concessions, superior to that of parastatal
            organizations for ports and railways. Thus, the
            concentration of investment with high volumes of traffic,
            lower operational costs, and relative autonomy from
            government, generally makes port concessions a relatively
            low risk for investors. Yet, if railways are likely to incur
            losses, and/or are inadequately compensated for uneconomic
            services, investors will be hard to come, and therefore
            bidding conditions, and the terms of the concession
            agreement will need to take this fact into account. The
            design of projects preparing parastatal companies for
            privatization should also consider the capacity, and
            commitment of government, and management to carry through
            the reform process. Targets and timetables should be
            realistic, and, special care should be placed in the
            selection of qualified consultants preparing bidding documentation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability is likely, and institutional development
            impacts are substantial. Regardless of success, key lessons
            convey that: 1) by and large, raising port services levels
            to international standards, is not usually feasible within
            the public sector framework. Therefore, it is essential that
            an appropriate institutional framework involve private
            sector participation, to sustain improvements to port
            systems, by creating domestic competition, leading to
            regional competition, and/or concession agreements, forcible
            enough to obtain regulations protecting public interests,
            but under an appropriate institutional framework; 2)
            divestiture programs should be undertaken by institutions
            not related to the enterprise undergoing restructuring,
            while the privatization policy should be central to the
            macroeconomic policy framework, to ensure an objective
            approach to divestiture, and in turn, provide an appropriate
            political backing to the process; 3) changing circumstances,
            or project performance itself, may lead to unforeseen
            negative results, such as waste of resources on components
            with negligible impacts, but a flexible project design may
            prevent, and/or facilitate such resources to more critical
            investments; and, 4) given the superb project coordination,
            the complexity of the project did not preclude success,
            however, records management should be considered at project design.

18149924.subsc: Ports, waterways and shipping,Central government administration
18149924.theme: Infrastructure services for private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the project is to
            expand the physical, managerial and operational capabilities
            of the Tanzania Harbours Authority (THA) to meet the traffic
            volume expected in the 1990s. The project will also provide
            a more reliable and cost effective transport link for
            neighboring landlocked countries, thus facilitating their
            overseas trade activities. The project includes: (a) civil
            works to expand the port container terminal, complete the
            Ubungo and Kurasini inland container depots, pave the
            lighterage wharf for container storage, construct a port
            access road, complete second phase of general cargo terminal
            rehabiliation and repair concrete piles and fenders; (b)
            rehabilitation of the port's central workshop and
            provision of technical assistance for training of mechanics;
            (c) procurement of container and general cargo handling
            equipment; and (d) management assistance and training for
            middle and upper management. It also includes: (e) technical
            assistance to Customs to introduce a simplified
            documentation process, computerize customs processing and
            train customs officers; (f) addition of a technical
            assistance and training coordinator to the Project
            Coordination Unit; (g) a development study to review the
            options for future port capacity expansion; and (h)
            consulting services for supervision of civil works and
            detailed engineering.
